list.text: My artwork attempts to represent five sea snail species under the taxonomic order Neogastropoda. As someone who lived in a coastal town in Southeast China throughout my younger ages, seashells are significant parts of my childhood memory. And as a student in Toronto today, I aim to explore my connection with seashells through the creation of this artwork. The species are chosen from the most memorable seashells in my childhood memory: Oliva mustelina is a delicate shell found on sandy beaches, Neptunea cumingii, Babylonia areolata, and Rapana venosa are among the most common local seafood, and Melo melo is both edible and decorative. I modelled these shells using parametric surfaces based on logarithmic spirals. While I intended to produce a rough visual appearance rather than capturing accurate anatomical details and sizes, I am glad with how this artwork allows me to express my unique background and lasting fascination with these sea creatures.

To see a list of my saved Desmos graphs, visit https://harry7557558.github.io/desmos/
To see a math grapher I coded from scratch (and example shapes), visit https://spirulae.github.io/

Test whether a quadrilateral patch is flipped after projection, used to test whether the surface exposed is the inner/outer side of the shell

How it works: calculate the (twice of) area of the projected quadrilateral, see if it's positive/negative (clockwise/counterclockwise)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoelace_formula#Triangle_formula
Function defining the canvas, less than zero is inside

Border

The parametric version based on the equation of polar rectangles seem to be the most stable

How it works: r = min(a|sec(θ)|, b|csc(θ)|) is the equation of an axis-aligned rectangle with width 2a and height 2b. Desmos fills parametric curves by nonzero rule.
Position and scaling, subscripts for the names of each shell
Position and scaling for text, English and Chinese

Trigonometric spline generated using this Python script (https://github.com/harry7557558/svg-to-desmos)

To use it on your own text (and other shapes):
 - Generate text using vector graphics software and export SVG with vectorized fonts
 - Set `EXPORT_SHAPE_MODE` in `merge_shapes.py` to True
 - Set path to SVG file and desired resolution in `main.py`, comment out `collect_shapes_greedy` and `extract_common_latex` lines
 - Run `main.py`, which should output a `.desmos` file
 - Open a blank regular Desmos graph, paste the content of `.desmos` file in F12 developer console and press Enter (WARNING: don't do this to code you don't trust on any website)
 - You should see shapes in the SVG file in the Desmos graph. Copy the expressions for corresponding shapes and paste to the graph you are working with

The script applies FFT-based lossy compression on text borders. You can balance accuracy and expression size by adjusting `scale` in `main.py`. The scripts was written intended for minimal graph size and does some "funky" optimization, like using one-letter names for sine and cosine.

English text (Neogastropoda)

Font: Lora, Open Font License

Chinese text (新腹足目)

Font: Droid sans, Apache license, designed by Steve Matteson of Ascender Corporation

How to model a conch:

Each seashell is modelled as a 2D cross section swept through a logarithmic spiral path, with addition of texture.

 - (x,y) = (c1(t),c2(t)) defines the 2D cross section to swept through. Swept curve parameter v may be added as an independent variable
 - r(u,v) defines the radius of the shell perpendicular to axis, either c1(u) or modified c1(u)

In each of the following shells, you can play with the sliders to see how they affect the shell's appearance:
 - k is the parameter for logarithmic spiral that controls how much the shell expands
 - o is the offset that defines how much the shell expands toward the axis

Equation of the shell (a swept surface):
 - x(u,v) = v^k sin(2π ln(v)) r(u,v)
 - y(u,v) = v^k cos(2π ln(v)) r(u,v)
 - z(u,v) = v^k (c2(u) - o) + o
where u is a periodic parameter with a period of 2π, v is greater than 0 (between 0 and 1 here)

Each seashell is discretized into quadrilaterals for rendering in 2D.
 - M: evenly split domain of u into M intervals
 - N: take N even samples for v from 1/N to 1

Followed by a "rendering pipeline"
 - Vertices and indices similar to those in mesh-based models
 - Project 3D points to 2D with depth
 - Sort quad patches by depth, patches behind will be covered when rendered

The first shell (Neptunea cumingii) will have full comments on how rendering works. Comments for later shells will be brief since the process is quite similar.

Special cases:
 - Rapana venosa has different colors for inner and outer sides of the shell, by testing the signed area of projected quadrilateral patch
 - Oliva mustelina has alternating shear patterns vertically on the shell that produce "parallelograms"

Cross section: trigonometric interpolating polynomial

You can generate the coefficients with a tool similar to this one:
https://www.desmos.com/calculator/gunquwlb7j
r(u,v), c1(u) with grid-like u-v texture

Discretization parameters, sample U and V

For V, it's sampled exponentially to give the same angular interval in the logarithmic spiral
Sort patches by depth, store it as indices to avoid sorting multiple times (which is slow)

Color: linear interpolation in HSV color space
 - I/M gives u, J/N gives v, cos(πJ) gives alternating values for patches along a line
 - (1-0.6v)^3: fade the color for shell tip
 - sin(8πu)^2 gives stripes
 - 0.9+0.1cos(πJ) gives alternating stripes in swept direction
 - the last term creates white dots on the shoulder of the shell

list.title: [top left] Babylonia areolata (花螺, flower/patterned snail)

list.text: Cross section, ellipse with a siphonal notch/canal
Discretization parameters, sample U and V

Color: linear interpolation in HSV color space
 - I/M gives u, J/N gives v, cos(π/2 I|J)^2 gives alternating 1 and 0 for patches along a line
 - first term: fade the color for shell tip
 - second term: patterns on the shell
 - third term: create a slight color gradient

list.title: [bottom left] Melo melo (吊螺, hanging snail? I found little relevant results by searching this name, some internet sources call it 椰子螺, coconut snail)

list.text:
Cross section, distorted and displaced ellipse

c1: the second term distorts the ellipse, the third term is for the folds on the column https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columella_%28gastropod%29
c2: the second term creates a siphonal notch

The folds don't show up on the discretized model. To see a high-quality rendering of the parametric surface, go to https://spirulae.github.io/paramsurf/ and paste the following:

c_mm1(t,v)=0.2+(1-(v(1-v))^0.7(1/2+1/2sin(t-2.2))^10)(0.9cos(t)+0.15sin(2t))-v(1-v)^2sin(30t)(1/2+1/2sin(t-2.2))^40
c_mm2(t,v)=1.5sin(t)+(0.15-0.1sin(t))|sin(t)|^(80+40sin(t))v^3
k_mm=0.88
o_mm=1.72
x=v^(k_mm)sin(2πln(v))c_mm1(2πu,v)
y=v^(k_mm)cos(2πln(v))c_mm1(2πu,v)
z=v^(k_mm)(c_mm2(2πu,v)-o_mm)+o_mm

Tip: you can do the same thing for other shells. The website supports LaTeX, you can directly copy-paste from Desmos as long as you change the (x|y|z)_subscript(u,v) to x|y|z for the parametric surface expression.
Discretization parameters, sample U and V

Color: linear interpolation in HSV color space
 - J/N gives v, cos(π/2 I|J)^2 gives alternating 1 and 0 for patches along a line
 - first term: create patterns on the shell
 - second term: fade the patterns near opening and tip

list.title: [bottom right] Rapana venosa (骨螺, bone snail, murex)

list.text:
Cross section, distorted and displaced circle

c1: distorted circle
c2: circle, distorted, with siphonal notch
r: add ridges on the shell
Discretization parameters, sample U and V

Color: linear interpolation in HSV color space
 - similar to previous shells
 - except for the addition of f that distinguishes the inner side of the shell, which has red-ish color

list.title: [top right] Oliva mustelina (榧螺, torreya snail?)

list.text: Cross section, distorted ellipse with siphonal notch

Parametric equation of the shell

d(u,v) creates parallelogram shapes on the shell after discretization to simulate the appearance of real shells under this specie
Discretization parameters, sample U and V

Color: linear interpolation in HSV color space
 - I/M gives u, J/N gives v, cos(π/2 I|J)^2 gives alternating 1 and 0 for each patch, sin(π/2 J) gives alternating [0,1,0,-1]
 - first term: fade the color for shell tip
 - second term: grid patterns on the shell
 - third term: create a slight color gradient
